Historic Britain Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street; (212) 966-6565, ext. 204 or 212.

The Royal Oak Foundation is offering a series of lectures starting on Wednesday at 6 P.M. with Timothy Knox, the architectural historian of the British National Trust. He will talk on the decorative arts collections in some of the 240 historic homes run by the National Trust.

Other lectures will include textile furnishings in the Tudor period (Feb. 18); interiors of the United States State Department reception rooms (Feb. 25), and the Arts and Crafts movement in Britain (April 29). A schedule is available. Fee, each lecture, $20; members, $12.
Talks on Architecture Avery Hall at Columbia University, Room 114, Broadway at 116th Street; (212) 854-8165.

A series of midday talks on perceptions of contemporary American architecture and culture starts tomorrow with a lecture titled ''The Art of the Missing Part'' by Hal Foster, a professor of modern art at Princeton University, and a response by Helen Molesworth, a professor of art history at SUNY Westbury.

Other talks in the series, each of which will feature two speakers and take place from 12:30 to 2 P.M., will be given on architecture and homeless people (Feb. 20); architecture in films (March 6); Colonial Williamsburg and historical accuracy (March 13), and the relationship between architectural theory and practice (April 3). No charge.
Talk by Tschumi Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue at St. James Place, Brooklyn; (718) 636-3471.
The Pratt Institute is sponsoring a lecture by the architect Bernard Tschumi, about his work, on Feb. 12 at 5 P.M. No charge.
